unsafe.description: Chocolate contains theobromine and caffeine, which are toxic to dogs and can cause vomiting, diarrhea, seizures, and even death.
Grapes and raisins can cause kidney failure in dogs, even in small amounts.
Raisins can cause kidney failure in dogs, even in small amounts.
Onions contain compounds that can damage red blood cells in dogs, leading to anemia.
Garlic is more toxic than onions and can cause anemia in dogs.
Avocados contain persin, which can cause vomiting and diarrhea in dogs.
Xylitol (artificial sweetener) can cause rapid insulin release, leading to hypoglycemia and liver failure.

safe.description: Carrots are safe and healthy for dogs, providing vitamins and helping clean teeth.
safe.preparation: Raw or cooked, cut into appropriate sizes

safe.description: Apples are safe for dogs when seeds and core are removed. High in vitamins A and C.
safe.preparation: Remove seeds and core, cut into slices
safe.caution: Remove seeds as they contain cyanide

safe.description: Blueberries are excellent for dogs, packed with antioxidants and vitamins.
safe.preparation: Fresh or frozen, serve in moderation

safe.description: Sweet potatoes are nutritious and safe for dogs when cooked.
Green beans are safe and low-calorie for dogs.
safe.preparation: Fresh, frozen, or canned (no salt), steamed or raw

caution.description: Most dogs can eat cheese in small amounts, but some are lactose intolerant.
caution.recommendation: Give in small amounts, watch for digestive issues

caution.description: Plain bread is generally safe but offers no nutritional value and can cause weight gain.
caution.recommendation: Only plain bread, avoid with raisins, nuts, or seeds
caution.caution: High in carbs, can cause weight gain

unsafe.description: Chocolate is toxic to cats and can cause vomiting, diarrhea, seizures, and death.
Onions can cause anemia in cats by damaging red blood cells.
Garlic is toxic to cats and can cause anemia.
Grapes can cause kidney problems in cats.
Raisins can cause kidney problems in cats.

safe.description: Plain cooked chicken is safe and healthy for cats.
Cooked fish is safe for cats and provides omega-3 fatty acids.
safe.preparation: Cooked, remove all bones, no seasoning

safe.description: Small amounts of cantaloupe are safe for cats.
safe.preparation: Small pieces, remove seeds and rind

caution.description: Many adult cats are lactose intolerant and may experience digestive issues.
Tuna is safe occasionally but shouldn't be a regular diet due to mercury content.
caution.recommendation: Occasional treat only, not as regular food
caution.caution: High mercury content, can cause mercury poisoning if fed regularly

unsafe.description: Chocolate is toxic to rabbits and can cause digestive issues and potentially death.
Iceberg lettuce can cause diarrhea and has little nutritional value for rabbits.
Onions can cause anemia and digestive problems in rabbits.
Garlic is toxic to rabbits and can cause anemia.
Avocado contains persin which is toxic to rabbits.

safe.description: Timothy hay is essential for rabbit digestion and dental health.
safe.preparation: Fresh, dry hay available at all times

safe.description: Carrots are safe for rabbits but should be given in moderation due to sugar content.
safe.preparation: Small pieces, 1-2 times per week as treats

safe.description: Romaine lettuce is safe and nutritious for rabbits.
Bell peppers are safe and provide vitamin C for rabbits.
Fresh grass is safe and natural for rabbits, providing fiber and nutrients.
safe.preparation: Fresh, pesticide-free grass from safe areas

caution.description: Most fruits are safe but high in sugar and should be limited.
caution.caution: Too much fruit can cause digestive upset and obesity

unsafe.description: Chocolate is extremely toxic to hamsters and can be fatal.
Onions can cause anemia in hamsters.
Garlic is toxic to hamsters and can cause blood disorders.
Citrus fruits are too acidic for hamsters and can cause digestive issues.

safe.description: Sunflower seeds are safe for hamsters but should be given in moderation.
Carrots are safe and nutritious for hamsters.
safe.preparation: Small pieces, remove if not eaten within 24 hours

safe.description: Broccoli is safe for hamsters in small amounts.

caution.description: Some nuts are safe but high in fat and should be limited.
caution.recommendation: Very small amounts, avoid salted nuts
caution.caution: High fat content can cause obesity

unsafe.description: Avocado is extremely toxic to birds and can cause sudden death.
Chocolate is toxic to birds and can cause seizures and death.
Caffeine can cause cardiac arrest in birds.
Salt can cause dehydration and kidney damage in birds.

safe.description: Millet is a favorite treat for many birds and is very safe.
Dark leafy greens are excellent for birds.
Most berries are safe and nutritious for birds.

caution.description: Fruit pits and seeds can contain cyanide.
caution.recommendation: Remove all pits and seeds before offering fruit
caution.caution: Apple seeds, cherry pits, etc. are toxic

unsafe.description: Turtles cannot digest dairy products and it can cause serious digestive issues.
Processed foods contain preservatives and chemicals harmful to turtles.
Bread has no nutritional value and can cause digestive problems.

safe.description: Dark leafy greens are essential for turtle nutrition.
High-quality commercial turtle food provides balanced nutrition.
safe.preparation: Follow package instructions for amount and frequency

caution.description: Some fish are safe but should be part of a balanced diet.
caution.recommendation: Offer variety, avoid fish as sole food source
caution.caution: Some fish can cause thiamine deficiency if fed exclusively

unsafe.description: Chocolate is toxic to fish and can contaminate water, causing serious health issues.
Bread can cause digestive problems and water quality issues.
Rice can expand in fish stomachs and cause digestive issues.
Dairy products can pollute water and cause digestive issues in fish.

safe.description: High-quality commercial fish food is formulated for optimal fish health.
Bloodworms are a natural food source for many fish species.
Brine shrimp are excellent live or frozen food for fish.
safe.preparation: Feed live, frozen, or freeze-dried brine shrimp

safe.description: Daphnia are small crustaceans that make excellent fish food.
safe.preparation: Feed live or frozen daphnia as treats

safe.description: Commercial fish flakes are formulated for balanced nutrition.
safe.preparation: Feed according to package instructions, avoid overfeeding

caution.description: Most human foods are not suitable for fish.
caution.caution: Human food can pollute water and harm fish

unsafe.description: Most lizards are insectivores and cannot properly digest fruits.
Lizards cannot digest dairy products.

safe.description: Crickets are an excellent protein source for most lizards.
Mealworms are a good protein source for many lizard species.

caution.description: Some lizards can eat vegetables, but it depends on the species.
caution.recommendation: Research your specific lizard species dietary needs
caution.caution: Carnivorous lizards cannot digest plant matter

unsafe.description: Snakes are strict carnivores and should only eat whole prey items.

safe.description: Mice are the primary food source for most pet snakes.
Rats are suitable for larger snake species.

caution.description: Live prey can injure snakes and is generally unnecessary.
caution.caution: Live prey can bite and injure your snake

unsafe.description: Chocolate is toxic to chickens and can cause death.
Avocado is toxic to chickens and can cause sudden death.
Onions can cause anemia in chickens.

safe.description: Grains like corn and wheat are excellent for chickens.
Leafy greens provide vitamins and minerals for chickens.
Most vegetables are safe and nutritious for chickens.

caution.description: Treats should not exceed 10% of a chicken's diet.
caution.recommendation: Limit treats to maintain balanced nutrition
caution.caution: Too many treats can cause nutritional imbalances
